title: Wednesday, 17th May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:02am

PM11:02am

Which is good

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Since it allows me to share just a little of the trash that arrives in my inbox each day.

PM11:02am

PM11:02am

You'll just have to wear it.

11:02 am
PM11:02am

So, the headline...

PM11:03am

Weak Pound Helping British Exporters

PM11:03am

and some accompanying guff

11:03 am
PM11:03am

While the fall in Sterling has caused pain to holidaymakers, it’s been a boon to exporters, since it means that UK exports become much more competitive on the international market. Of course, while it’s always good to make hay while the sun shines, it’s important to look long-term too as currencies can and do rise and fall according to market circumstances.

What the weak pound means

The weak pound basically means that British-produced goods and services effectively become more affordable. It does, however, also mean that it becomes more expensive to buy goods and services from overseas. This has several implications. One is that people in the UK have more of an incentive to “buy British” when possible. Another is that international customers may see a weak pound as a buying opportunity, at least for non-perishable items or may place orders now to be fulfilled at a future date. On the flip side, however, it may cause British companies to postpone, or at least scale back, investment, until such time as the Pound rises and it becomes cheaper to make purchases on the international markets.

PM11:03am

blah blah blah bal

PM11:03am

h

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Why is the pound weak (and when is it likely to rise again)?

Currency markets (and indeed markets in general) tend to dislike uncertainty. The Pound’s current rough ride and extended periods in the doldrums date back to the announcement of the Brexit referendum, although in the early stages, markets were only mildly perturbed by it since “Remain” seemed a foregone conclusion. When reality struck, the markets took fright and although it has lurched upwards from time to time, overall the Pound has been somewhat stuck in a rut ever since. The latest event to unsettle the markets was the triggering of Article 50, which marks the start of the official Brexit negotiating process. The question of when it is likely to rise again is more complicated. The Brexit process can take up to two years (in fact it could take longer if there is mutual agreement). We would therefore suspect that the Pound’s standing in the currency markets will be pretty much a direct reflection of the perceived progress (or lack thereof) in these talks. If it seems likely that there will be a hard Brexit, we would expect the Pound to stay (relatively) weak, whereas if the UK secures a deal to access the single market as part of a soft Brexit, it seems reasonable to assume that the Pound will rise again.

Colgate-Palmolive could be looking to sell

By Claire Atkinson and Josh Kosman

May 16, 2017 | 11:00pm

Colgate-Palmolive’s chief executive recently signaled he would be open to selling the company — which has grappled with sluggish demand for its toothpaste, deodorants and food products — for $100 a share, a source told The Post.

CEO Ian Cook’s stated price tag, valuing the consumer-products giant at more than $88 billion, came at a meeting with institutional investors that took place in recent weeks, a source with knowledge of the conversation said.etc

BE11:17am

In ‘market Top Trumps' the US President trumps just about everything else, at least in the very short term. “Comey memo says Trump asked FBI Chief to drop Flynn probe” is the FT headline on the story doing the damage overnight, though we do also have softer oil prices after the release of strong US inventory data. 10-year Treasury yields are 4bp lower than when markets closed yesterday evening, 10bp lower than they were on Thursday before the US CPI and retail sales data releases. European yields are opening lower too, but the 10year has narrowed to 189bp, and the Treasury/JGB spread to 226bp.

The yen is the FX winner, still faithfully tracking Treasuries, and getting ready to test the hypothesis that in the current climate, any sell-off for risk assets is a short-term affair that will be followed by investors returning in the search for yield. I suppose the question is whether these are US political rain showers like the ones drenching London's commuters, or real storms with lasting damage. Only time will tell but while the appetite to come back and hunt for yield does start to decrease after a while, we still tend to think this sell-off will be short-lived.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

So, Morgan Stanley can talk us through the figures.

BE11:22am

Sophos reported a very strong uFCF beat in H2 17 along with solid Billings and Cash EBITDA, in-line with their Trading Update. FY18 and new mid-term guidance suggests significant upgrades to street on Billings and uFCF out to 2020; we expect the shares to do well today.

BE11:22am

Solid H2 Billings and Cash EBITDA, in-line with trading update: Sophos reported H2 billings of $352m (org. growth +c.27% in Q4), +0% vs MSe and +3% ahead of consensus. Growth was driven by both Network and Endpoint with continued strength in Sophos Central (+220% for FY17) and the new Intercept X product, now with more than 8000 customers. On Cash EBITDA, Sophos came in at $99.2m in H2 (28.2% margin), +4% ahead of consensus and in-line with MSe. A high level of deferred revenues means revenue growth was slightly more muted at $272.8m, 3% below consensus.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

("Cash Ebitda" grumble grumble.)

BE11:23am

uFCF stands out: Sophos reported underlying FCF of $71.2m in H2, +64% ahead of MSe at $43.3m and +75% ahead of cons at $40.7m. We understand this was partly benefitted by working capital timing, with an underlying run-rate at c. $120m, which would have been a c.+40% beat vs consensus.

BE11:23am

Solid FY 18 guide: Sophos expects mid to high‐teens billings growth for FY18, ahead of MSe (+13% growth) and cons (+15% growth but from a lower base). On margins, Sophos expects a 50‐100 basis point improvement in the cash EBITDA margin on the FY17 base of 23.7%, ahead of consensus at 23.7% for FY18 and slightly above MSe at 24.2%. Given the significant cash flow beat in FY17 Sophos expects broadly flat uFCF in FY18, ahead of consensus at $116.6m and in-line with MSe.

Mid-term guide significantly ahead: Sophos anticipates achieving billings of c.$1 billion by FY20, c.17% ahead our current forecasts. Combined with an annual 100‐150 basis point cash EBITDA margin improvement, this translates into unlevered free cash flow in the range $220 million to $240 million, c.37% ahead of our current expectations for $168m of uFCF at the mid-point. Given FY20 revenue consensus is currently c.6% ahead of MSe, we believe the mid-term guidance would also be significantly ahead of current consensus.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

And Shore, since they're sellers.

BE11:25am

Clearly Sophos has performed very strongly this year and has confidence of continued performance. Whilst we retain some concerns over fundamental valuation and medium term competition in the mid-market, we acknowledge pressure on our SELL recommendation and will proffer further thoughts post the analyst meeting.

For the medium-term, we anticipate achieving billings of c.$1 billion, unlevered free cash flow in the range of $220 million to $240 million and around a 100-150 basis point cash EBITDA margin improvement per annum giving adjusted operating profit of $100+ million by FY20.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Anyway, Ian Gordon of Investec celebrates the news with a 75p target.

BE11:28am

As widely anticipated, the UK Government has now completed the selldown of its £20.3bn (43.3%) “investment” made during 2009, to zero. As discussed in our report, Glad it’s all over? (16 May), in practical terms, this immediately removes the technical drag on the share price of Government share sales of up to 15% of the average daily volume. We do not anticipate any consequential change in strategy. Lloyds is already a “recovered” bank with significantly enhanced dividend-paying capacity. Let the good times roll!

BE11:29am

[W]e believe that Lloyds’ strategy and outlook is set fair, irrespective of its evolving ownership or management. In balance sheet terms, we continue to see it as a “no growth” bank, albeit this conceals an ongoing positive mix effect as it rebalances the composition of its lending portfolios. We see the acquisition of MBNA, expected to complete in Q2 2017, as a clear positive in this regard.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Lloyds shares have enjoyed a tailwind over the past ten months as consensus expectations in relation to NIM, impairment and DPS have started to catch up to a (pretty glorious) reality. However, following a 10% beat vs u/l PBT consensus in Q1 2017 we see this upgrade cycle as “unfinished business”. Our EPS forecasts of 5.5-6.7p through 2017-2019e remain ahead of Bloomberg consensus (5.3-6.5p) while our DPS forecasts of 4.5-5.5p through 2017-2019e are seemingly further ahead; Bloomberg consensus has 3.8-4.7p.

Lloyds trades on 1.2x Q1 2017 tNAV for ROTEs of 10-11% through 2017-2019e, supplemented by a prospective dividend yield of 6.4% in 2017e, rising to 7.8% by 2019e. Our Buy recommendation and 75p target price are both reaffirmed.

PM11:29am

Wonder what Eric Daniels is up to these days?

PM11:30am

Every day on here back in 2008/9 we use to write: "Eric Daniels, what have you done?"

11:31 am
BE11:31am

The flipside of Ian's argument is, of course, that you can pay 1.2x NAV for a bank that's pretty much 100% UK exposed and has a lot of unsecured lending and residential mortgage debt on the books, which whatever your overall view of a post-Brexit Britain can be considered to carry some specific concentrated risks.

BE11:32am

Or you can pay 0.8x tNAV for a bank that's in some possibly trickier markets, but is in a lot more of them.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

Kingfisher PLC (KGF:LSE): Last: 367.10, up 8.9 (+2.48%), High: 367.20, Low: 360.10, Volume: 4.35m
PM11:35am

What's the story there?

BE11:35am

Well, good Stifel note yesterday taking apart Screwfix, which we mentioned in the paper overnight.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

And as of today we have HSBC pushing.

BE11:36am

Big sector thing. Category killers mostly downgraded, except Kingfisher.

BE11:37am

Generally very negative on the UK. Inflation, wage erosion, input costs rising, etc.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Against a backdrop of increasing macro risk we take a more cautious view. While we have consistently noted threats to the UK consumer outlook, data post the Brexit referendum has been robust. However, cracks are now appearing and the inflationary headwinds that have concerned us are becoming increasingly obvious. As a result we see increasing threats to demand as we move through the year. Accelerating inflation has seen real wage growth turn negative suggesting consumers' budgets are being squeezed. In addition, inflation in inelastic areas such as food is accelerating, which will further squeeze discretionary demand. The situation is made worse for non-food retailers as cost inflation is feeding through as hedging programmes roll off. In aggregate this suggests in the second half of the year, non-food retailers may face a period of falling demand and rising costs; a toxic combination.

PM11:38am

(Groundhog Day -- actually a did traipse over to Mayfair yesterday in search of info. Was told to come back next week... )

BE11:38am

.... after that, HSBC's broken each of its calls out as a separate note. I'll try and summarise as best I can.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Here's Kingfisher.

BE11:39am

The Kingfisher transformation plan is radical, ambitious and has a lower risk than headline performance targets suggest: We take a closer look at the transformation plan from the bottom-up and at its ability to deliver shareholder value via a targeted GBP500m uplift in EBITA by FY21e. We believe that the execution risk attached to key elements of the plan, particularly the unified product and offer, is not as high as the headline performance targets suggest (a year 2 unified product target of 20%). We also consider management is ahead of plan on this and other parts of the transformation key to its success, including the low risk implementation of new IT systems into the UK and France. Long term this transformation will see Kingfisher leverage the combined buying power of 9 separate Opcos into a competitive advantage in price.

Against a backdrop of relatively supportive DIY markets, we forecast a three-year EPS CAGR of 11%: The European home improvement market is worth GBP235bn, of which Kingfisher has a c5% share. This includes 320m homes many of which are under-invested. A desire to live in better homes and cost constraints lead c60% of Europeans to undertake DIY every year. We expect demand in key markets in France to benefit from an improving macro outlook and removal of political uncertainty post the Presidential election. In the UK, we consider the relatively defensive nature of DIY vs other product categories and low interest rates will support housing market transaction activity.

BE11:39am

So, it's mostly an "avoid UK" play. Up to 65% of sales come from international.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

For the others -- Halfords, N Brown etc, the Dunelm summary captures the themes.

BE11:40am

UK consumer demand at risk. We have increased the risk profile of all our UK stocks under coverage in Recalibrating to reflect rising risk , 17 May 2017. This is due to the threat posed by inflation in inelastic areas, a return to real wage declines and increasing pressure from cost inflation. Dunelm has exposure to areas of discretionary spend that put it at risk of a downturn. In fact, even while demand has held up recently, Dunelm's end markets appear to have been soft. This could get worse if pressure on the consumer increases. At the same time, cost inflation is feeding through and while Dunelm's strategy of passing through "cost plus margin" may be fine, it increases risk. Over recent years, price aggressive online pure plays and discounters have become an increasing feature in many categories and their increased presence limits the margin for error in pricing strategy.

Dunelm Group PLC (DNLM:LSE): Last: 592.32, down 23.68 (-3.84%), High: 606.00, Low: 586.00, Volume: 488.20k

PM11:45am

Why's Auto trader off 4.5%??

BE11:45am

Berenberg!

11:45 am
Auto Trader Group PLC (AUTO:LSE): Last: 399.80, down 19.5 (-4.65%), High: 413.40, Low: 399.80, Volume: 1.59m
BE11:45am

Starts with a 350p target.

BE11:45am

They've had a look at the business and found that it's a website.

11:45 am
PM11:45am

hehehehe

BE11:46am

It's a quite nice website! But ... y'know.

BE11:46am

We initiate coverage of Auto Trader with a Sell rating and a price target of GBp350, offering c15% downside from current levels. While the company has a clear market-leading position and is likely to report solid top-line growth over the coming years, we think there are good reasons to believe that this growth may be slower and less profitable than consensus expects. We thus see the valuation as unappealing with downside risk to the premium multiples.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

And of course it's involved in the selling of cars, so we get to play "autonomous car disruption bingo."

BE11:47am

Current used-car trends create risks to growth: Classified websites such as Auto Trader’s are strongest and have most pricing power when markets are highly fragmented. However, we expect car dealer consolidation to continue, which could put downwards pressure on both pricing growth and stock levels. Additionally, while used-car sales in the UK are at record levels, supported by a boom in PCP finance, our analysis suggests this level of transactions is at risk and that tighter credit requirements may soften usedcar demand. Further to this, electric vehicles, car sharing and autonomous cars could all have a negative impact in the medium to long term.

BE11:47am

Plus, well ... it's a website.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Other website models can cause disruption: While all used cars are different, the fact that price is the most important factor when choosing a car makes it a more commoditised market, in our view. Consumers spend more than 12 hours researching online what used car to buy, and experts advise to scour all corners of the internet for the best deal. It is this strong “getting a good deal” behaviour that gives competing websites such as CarGurus a fighting chance for disruption, in our view.

BE11:48am

.... a website that's doing the "get an installed customer base then hike prices and hope they stay installed" thing ......

BE11:48am

In FY 2016/FY 2017, Auto Trader’s average
revenue per retailer forecourt growth has largely been a result of price increases. The company aims for balanced growth across its four pillars and we expect FY 2018 and FY 2019 to be more of an upsell/cross-sell story. Revenue growth from these pillars may prove tougher than raising prices, especially if new products are less appreciated than the company expects.

11:48 am

Auto Trader’s valuation looks unappealing to us,
particularly relative to its online peers. Our DCF suggests a fair value of GBp350, or c15% downside. Looking at multiples, the company trades on a calendar 2017 EV/EBITDA and P/E of 19.4x and 24.9x respectively, and we believe the risks we highlight are not captured in these premium multiples.

BE11:52am

See? Expensive.

Hikma Pharmaceuticals PLC (HIK:LSE): Last: 1,729, down 37 (-2.10%), High: 1,749, Low: 1,699, Volume: 527.20k
BE11:54am

Jefferies. Advair. Delay. You know the gist.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We double downgrade from Buy to Underperform and lower 2017/2018 EPS by c.25%. We believe the delay to Gx Advair (JEFe 2H ’18) is likely to significantly impact NT expectations. (-10% are post FY changes). We expect a cautious IMS on May 19. Although momentum in injectables remains robust, we believe the delay is likely to act as a serious drag to sentiment until the US business turns around; hence our double downgrade. PT lower to 1450p.

BE11:55am

Which all feels like old ground, though interesting line is .....

BE11:55am

we had assumed a hefty greater than 47% EBITA margin for Gx Advair as we believe all royalty payments do not impact EBITA; this magnifies the EPS downgrade.

11:55 am
PM11:55am

BE11:55am

BE11:56am

11:55 am
undefined
BE11:56am

Oh, someone yesterday was asking about Hargreaves, which we ignored.

BE11:57am

Not autopricing. It's up 0.8%.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Having dived about 9% by the end of yesterday.

BE11:58am

In one of those slow-gathering momentum sells as everyone looked at Vanguard's pricing and said, "oh, hang on ...."

BE11:59am

This morning, the sellside all saying "it's fine tho!" People will want to pay 1.2% all-in rather than 0.3% because they /love Harvgreaves!"

11:59 am
PM11:59am

Really?

BE11:59am

Yep. Here's Barclays, HL's house broker.

BE11:59am

We had known Vanguard was launching a low cost D2C platform in the UK since Dec-16 so we believe this is an over-reaction. The example fee structure detailed by Vanguard averaging 29bps is low compared to Hargreaves but the services are not comparable in our opinion. We believe customers want to consolidate their wealth in one easy-to-use online platform. The limitations of the Vanguard offering is likely to be that it is restricted to only offering Vanguard product.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

The potential threat from Vanguard is not to be taken likely but the limitations of its offering need to be noted. It is also debatable how established a brand Vanguard is for direct distribution into the UK. Without a significant marketing budget from the US parent, Vanguard may struggle to acquire customers. We believe Hargreaves' existing customers are unlikely to view the hassle of switching as worth the effort. A major attraction of the HL offering is being able to consolidate all manufacturers in multi assets classes and product wrappers in one place.

BE11:59am

Vanguard detailed a fund platform fee of 15bps and an average manufacturing fee of 14bps ie 29bps all in. Hargreaves charges c.45bps for its platform fee and the same 14bps manufactured fund charges, i.e 59bps. But it is debatable how price sensitive customers are and the service offerings are not comparable between the two, in our opinion.

BE12:00pm

And Numis, which is Hargreaves' other house broker.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

In our opinion Vanguard has a few fundamental problems with its offer. It is not open architecture (like the F&C offering you can only have in-house product), you can't have a SIPP, you can't buy shares and the brand is not known outside of the City. There have been a number of low cost competitors that have made no progress against HL including those with deep pockets and a strong brand like Lloyds Banking Group. We believe that not being able to have all of your assets in one place is a fundamental deal breaker and we are not concerned about the Vanguard offering. The OCF charges are the same but their platform fee is 15bps, not that price is the most important factor in choosing a platform for the majority of people. HL have their four month trading update on Thursday.

BE12:00pm

Structural growth: We believe that, even without the growth that we expect to come from the HL savings businesses, HL offers investors a structural growth opportunity. The shift from institutionally managed defined benefit pension schemes to retail managed defined contribution schemes is expected to see the average client portfolio triple in size. Additionally the shift to individually managed portfolios away from advisor management has commenced. In the US it has fallen from 80% of assets to less than 50% in a decade and we believe the UK will follow a similar path. We see these two trends driving growth in AuA of c.15% per annum for at least the next decade. A combination of RDR repricing and the fall in interest earned on client cash has seen profitability lag AuA growth in recent years. With these impacts largely behind the group pricing we believe AuA growth will drive profit growth.

BE12:00pm

And Shore, which isn't Hargreaves' house broker.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

For those individual investors who want to invest in passives only (the FCA would appear to want everyone to do this, based on November’s Asset Management Market Study), the new Vanguard platform charges a platform fee of 15bps compared to HL’s 45bps (for funds), up to a value of £250k.
Adding in the typical ongoing charge figure (OCF) of the underlying Vanguard funds (note that only Vanguard products are offered on the new platform) of c15bps (this varies slightly with the different products) then the all-in cost would be c30bps. There is a cap on the annual platform fee at £375 (equivalent to £250k of assets – but remember the current average HL customer has c£80k in its Vantage platform).

BE12:01pm

It has been the case for some time that it would be economically irrational for any client wanting to hold only passive funds to use HL (paying 3x as much in platform fees as the cost of the underlying products). But that’s why HL clients don’t do this ! HL have a low single digit % of total Assets under Administration in passives and even these are generally owned by clients who typically also choose to hold active funds and indeed some direct individual shares/bonds within different ISA/SIPP tax wrappers. While it would be financially rational for a client to move any passive assets to Vanguard from a cost point of view, for the level of assets we’re talking about (3% of an average £80k balance, or £2.4k), the saving would be £7 per annum – this doesn’t meet the convenience test for us (even before HL’s forthcoming cash savings product makes that relationship even more sticky).
The HL business model has proved itself to be incredibly resilient in the face of a couple of major headwinds in recent years, the RDR-required switch to platform fees (paid by directly by investors) from commissions (paid by product providers), and also the dramatically reduced ability to earn a net interest margin on client cash balances. We would be a lot more nervous around the implications of the Vanguard platform for the fledgling robo-advice sector. These services also make extensive use of passives to keep costs low but charge a fee on top for auto-rebalancing asset allocation, which is based on a high level risk assessment (it has to be high level in order not to cross the threshold into regulated advice). These types of services have an all-in price of around 100bps and many are still in the process of building sufficient scale to be profitable. Vanguard’s pricing looks particularly threatening to this segment in our view.

BE12:02pm

All of which is fair enough. But when you're trading at 30x and doing 45% margins and someone arrives charging a third of your prices, it's still not entirely convincing.
